discussion_comments.comment_body:
This doesn't seem right, and if you want to call `looseEqual`, the fast path here doesn't make sense.

see https://github.com/vuejs/core/commit/2ffb956efe692da059f4895669084c5278871351
![image](https://github.com/vuejs/core/assets/3705199/24d194e0-7b78-43da-adf7-53143c825b3d)

Maybe the fast path can only for number values for now. There may already be a large number of users using like https://github.com/vuejs/core/issues/10574.
For string values, keep the old logic.
Maybe both the string type and number type should retain the fast path. I added type judgment and I don’t know whether it will have an impact on the fast channel.

- fast path means without using `looseEqual`
- Your code does the same thing as `looseIndexOf`
I'm aware of that, I added a new commit to handle the same type directly, and only use looseEqual when it's different.

how about this?
```js
option.selected = value.some(v => String(v)===String(optionValue))
```
That makes sense, my brother. Why didn't I think of that?

Should be able to reuse `traverse` by adding a second argument:

```js
traverse(value: unknown, shallow = false, seen?: Set<unknown>)
```

The time complexity of `queue.shift()` is O(n), so it can be optimized by tracking the index manually:

```js
const queue: Array<[any, number]> = []
let queueIndex = 0

const [currentValue, currentDepth] = queue[queueIndex++]
```
